metadata.case_name: Sarupchand Hukamchand & Co. v. Union of India

facts.text: Appellant assessee firm Messrs. Sarupchand and Hukamchand and Co. carried on business as shroffs, merchants and commission agents at Bombay, Indore, Ujjain and Calcutta.
Firm had two partners: Sir Sarupchand Hukamchand (liable as Hindu undivided family) and Sri Hiralal Kalyanmal (liable as individual).
Assessment years concerned: 1940-41, 1941-42, 1942-43 (corresponding to account years 1995-1996 Samvat to 1997-1998 Samvat).
ITO, Section VIII (Central), Bombay, treated firm as resident and ordinarily resident.
For 1940-41, ITO found profit of Rs. 80,358, treated unregistered firm as registered u/s 23(5)(b), assessed partners individually, made demand on firm on March 15, 1945.
Application for registration u/s 26A rejected on March 15, 1945, as no instrument of partnership disclosed.
For 1941-42 (order July 31, 1945): Assessed unregistered firm on total income Rs. 2,30,798.
For 1942-43 (order October 31, 1945): British Indian income Rs. 2,62,827, total income Rs. 7,00,116, assessed as unregistered.

Assessee appealed assessments; AAC in consolidated appeals order dated April 29, 1949: Firm non-resident, excluded income outside British India; 1940-41 loss Rs. 1,61,084 total world income; variations for other years; directed ITO to modify assessments accordingly.

AAC findings: 1940-41: British India loss Rs. 2,26,028, outside Rs. 74,944, total loss Rs. 1,61,084; 1941-42: British India Rs. 1,27,062, outside Rs. 1,08,236, total Rs. 2,35,298; 1942-43: British India Rs. 2,62,827, outside Rs. 4,41,789, total Rs. 7,04,616.
ITO gave effect u/s 31: Carried 1940-41 loss to partners' assessments, refunded Rs. 16,977-11-0 to Sir Sarupchand Hukamchand and Rs. 68,339 to Sri Hiralal Kalyanmal.

Assessee claimed via letter September 10, 1949, and applications u/s 35 to ITO and AAC: Since loss in 1940-41, cannot treat as registered, entitled to carry forward loss to subsequent years as unregistered firm.
ITO and AAC declined rectification u/s 35: s.23(5)(b) order not appealable, final; 4-year period expired.
Assessee approached Commissioner and Central Board of Revenue, relief denied.
AAC later directed ITO to take 1940-41 losses to partners' accounts (omitted earlier); assessee applied July 16, 1951 to Additional ITO, reserved rights; partners withdrew refunds.
Assessee filed petition u/Art.226 in Bombay HC against Union of India and two ITOs for mandamus to give effect to AAC order treating as unregistered for carry forward.
Tendolkar J. dismissed Misc. No. 48/1952 on July 8, 1952: Possible two views on survival of s.23(5)(b) order, not fit for mandamus.
LP Appeal No. 108/1952 dismissed February 26, 1953 by Chagla CJ and Shah J: Possible two views per proviso (d) s.24(2); hope taxing authorities not deny rights on technical grounds.

legal_issues.text: Whether the ITO's order under s.23(5)(b) treating unregistered firm as registered survives when AAC converts profit into loss, or falls automatically, entitling firm to carry forward loss as unregistered.
Whether ITO must reapply mind under s.23(5)(b) after AAC's determination of loss to check if more revenue realizable by treating as registered.
Interpretation of proviso (d) to s.24(2): Does it allow carrying losses of unregistered firm treated as registered to partners regardless of revenue interest.
Whether mandamus appropriate against ITOs, and if High Court erred in not issuing writ.

petitioner_arguments.text: Action under s.23(5)(b) conditioned on realizing more revenue; loss means loss to revenue if carried to partners, outside ITO jurisdiction.
AAC's loss determination makes previous s.23(5)(b) order fall automatically; direction to modify assessments reopens entire question including treatment as registered.
Entitled to carry forward loss to subsequent years as unregistered firm.

respondent_arguments.text: Petition against wrong parties (Union, ITOs cannot grant relief); mandamus inappropriate as s.23(5)(b) order not appealable.
s.23(5)(b) order final, not appealed; AAC appeal only on quantum, direction under s.31(3)(a) does not set aside s.23(5)(b).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.30, s.31(3)(a) Indian Income-tax Act; CIT v. Khemchand Ramdas; CIT v. Tribune Trust

respondent_arguments.text: Proviso (d) s.24(2) allows losses of unregistered firm assessed as registered to be carried forward as if registered.

court_reasoning.text: s.23(5)(b) confers option on ITO to treat unregistered as registered only if more tax from partners; jurisdiction based on profit finding, AAC's loss reversal destroys substratum, order falls automatically.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reversal of profit into loss by AAC annulled assessment; ITO must reapply mind de novo under s.23(5)(b).

court_reasoning.text: Even if under s.31(3)(a), effect is annulment; no authorization under s.31(4) or proviso s.24(2) to carry loss to partners without rechecking revenue interest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: ITO required to determine afresh if interests of revenue served by s.23(5)(b).

court_reasoning.text: Proviso (d) s.24(2) enabling, not general power; applies 'during any year' when prior losses carried if revenue benefits; must read with s.23(5)(b) condition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No power to detriment of revenue; words 'during any year' limit to contingent cases.

court_reasoning.text: AAC's consolidated order for three years placed matter prior to s.23(5)(b) decision; ITO failed duty to reconsider.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mandamus appropriate to compel ITO to hear and determine per law.

court_reasoning.text: Preliminary objections rejected: Relief against ITOs proper; SC can grant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court erred in not issuing writ.

holdings.text: ITO's order u/s 23(5)(b) does not survive AAC's conversion of profit to loss; falls automatically, ITO must reconsider afresh if more revenue by treating as registered.
Proviso (d) s.24(2) subject to s.23(5)(b) revenue condition; not general permission to carry losses to partners.
Mandamus lies against ITOs to perform statutory duty.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay and Aden v. Khemchand Ramdas
precedents_cited.relevance: Assessment final subject to ss.34,35; distinguished as here assessment appealed and modified by AAC.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Tribune Trust, Lahore
precedents_cited.relevance: Final assessment not altered except ss.34,35; distinguished, s.23(5)(b) order not final like assessment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. McMillan & Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: AAC cannot review s.23(5)(b) if appealed directly; here power under s.31 annuls assessment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Amritlal Bhogilal & Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar to McMillan; AAC power under s.31 includes annulment affecting prior s.23(5)(b).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs assessment of unregistered firms as registered if more revenue; AAC powers to annul/modify; carry forward losses; rectification.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ of mandamus against ITOs to enforce statutory duty.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgments set aside; appropriate ITO directed to hear and determine matter under s.23(5)(b) in light of AAC order and SC observations; partners to refund amounts received before ITO decision.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ of mandamus to compel ITO to reconsider s.23(5)(b) application afresh.
outcome.costs: Costs throughout to be paid by respondents 2 and 3 (ITOs); Union of India bears own costs.

key_quotes.text: "The reversal of the finding of profit destroyed the substratum of the jurisdiction of the Income-tax Officer to act under that clause and his order automatically fell through."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on survival of s.23(5)(b) order post-loss determination.

key_quotes.text: "The Income-tax Officer in the light of the losses determined by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, was under a duty to apply his mind de novo to the problem."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Mandates ITO reconsideration for revenue interest.

key_quotes.text: "We should, therefore, by a writ compel them to do so."
key_quotes.speaker: court
